students.name: Alana Eve Lacy
students.title: Western Girl In Japan
students.desc: I want to create this piece of design to immortalise in hard copy the most liberating, soul-shaking, freedom-encapsulating, serotonin-fuelled self discovery 3 week mission of my 21 years lived thus far. The many people I met and the many places I went. Not only would this piece of design be a memoir to myself, but if composed beautifully enough, be a piece of consumable media for the individual who is naturally artistically inclined and presents an interest in indulging in my artwork composed in a digestible publication. It’s also a project; once manufactured; could go on to become commercially stocked in bookstores. It’s my dream to produce a hardcover book to the high standard of those stocked at Readings or Metropolis.

students.name: Angus Wicks
students.title: Solace
students.desc: Solace is a skate street wear brand. The aim being to capture the Melbourne street wear scene and incorporate aspects of skating and where i grew up in Fitzroy to produce clothing and accessories which mirror this. Solace skate street wear is not just about the clothes, it is a subculture that embodies a certain attitude and lifestyle.

students.name: Charles Ly
students.title: Affinite Rings
students.desc: Queer people have become cultural innovators at their own demise. Identifying other queer people has never been more difficult now that even the heterosexuals are cuffing their jeans! 'Affinite Rings' was a UX design project the centred around creating a new way for queer people to meet each other by capitalising on the history of queer signalling and reimagining it in a new and discreet way! Instead of subtle fashion choices like pierced ears or the hankerchief code, Affinite Rings are marketed as a way to make friends, allowing you fistbump someone to add them on social media. Way to appropriate straight culture!

students.name: Deniz Caliskan
students.title: Experiment 001
students.desc: The project is a collection of mechanical body installations which materialise the concept of the mind as an independent, non-material entity existing alongside and separate to the ‘shell’ of the human form.

students.name: Finn Stewart
students.title: To Build A Home
students.desc: Through this series To Build A Home, artist and designer Finn Stewart manifests the potential of post-consumer material– fashioning functionalist forms imbued with idiosyncratic readings. Through his gestures of upcycling, he finds a vernacular of contradiction which oscillates between rational non-functionalism and irrational functionalism. Finn humorously references canonical designs of the minimalist art period. As in the case of “Donald Crudd”, he borrows Judd’s simplistic model, juxtaposing it with reclaimed material and ultimately puts the modernist form on trial. Through his intuitive process of selection and assemblage, Finn leaves human impressions on that which is typically mass produced. The comfort and value found in these flawed objects brings home the precarious and catalytic nature of this artist’s lifestyle. They are his artifacts of lived experience, caught between crosswinds of desire and austerity.

students.name: Katya Vergana
students.title: Grimm's Fairy Tales
students.desc: A book containing selected works from the Brother's Grimm collection of fairy tales with new original illustrations.

students.name: Paul Weedon
students.title: Welcome to the Dream State
students.desc: This project is research towards a non linear story told through images from the language of dreams. It is presented as a speculative publication. I have combined personal experience and the visual vocabularies of painters, writers and myth-makers in an attempt to create an artefact which reflects the dream state in an authentic way. Our dreams are personal, but are they unique? Can I describe a syntax or language that is shared, recognisable and self evident?

students.name: Raquel Laing-Nobrega
students.title: Slice
students.desc: ‘Slice’ is an illustrative zine showcasing quotes from a diary I kept in high school, displaying them alongside graphics in a comic-style format. This zine publication translates the incoherent ramblings of a troubled teen into visual information in a comedic and entertaining way. Acting as a strong expression of self, I intend to express my own individualism by vocalizing my experiences. The zine is bound by a saddle-stitched, A5 in size and 24 pages long. Each quote is accompanied by a satirical illustration, printed with a Risograph printer to produce vibrant colours.

students.name: Rongshen Liang
students.title: Chinese Motifs & Cultural Significance
students.desc: My work explores the intersection of traditional Chinese motifs and modern aesthetics, reflecting my deep-rooted appreciation for history and passion for innovation. Inspired by the philosophies of Buddhism, Taoism, and Confucianism, I strive to encapsulate their essence in my designs, creating a dialogue between the ancient and contemporary. With each piece, I embark on a journey of self-discovery, seeking to understand my identity and heritage better, while sharing the beauty of Chinese culture with the world. This book is a testament to that journey and an invitation to join me in exploring these captivating motifs.

students.name: Xiaohui Jjia
students.title: Bug Buddies
students.desc: Bug Buddies is a blind box brand featuring a little boy dressed up as various insects. Each blind box includes a random little boy toy with a different insect theme and design.

students.name: Zixin Liu Alexis
students.title: Wine Brand Item Design
students.desc: A series of applications for wine branding based on the primary artwork I have drawn.

students.name: Ziyu Shen
students.title: Scientism
students.desc: This project challenges the notion that science and religion are mutually exclusive by exploring their intricate relationship. While religion is often seen as emotional and superstitious, and science as calm and objective, there is a dialectical cognition of things in religion that conforms to the spirit of science. Conversely, those who believe that science is the only means of understanding the world are embracing the spirit of religion. The project presents the scientific symbol system in religious visual form and presents religious concepts with scientific infographic forms, revealing the complex intertwinement of science and religion. By creating something scientific yet imbued with religious and metaphysical connotations, the project aims to encourage the audience to think about the combination of science and religion and to challenge their dualistic view of the two.
